unnormalised: So, someone asked about how addresses work in India, especially residential ones. It's a bit different depending on where you are, but here’s a general overview based on my experience. It can get pretty confusing, especially when you're trying to ship something!
normalised: So, someone asked about how addresses work in India, especially residential ones. It is a bit different depending on where you are, but here is a general overview based on my experience. It can get pretty confusing, especially when you are trying to ship something!

unnormalised: Firstly, the format usually starts with the most specific part – your house number or flat number. For example, "Flat No. 201" or "House No. 123". In apartment complexes, you'll often see something like "A-201" where "A" is the block or building name. It's super important to get this right because the postman might just end up delivering it to the wrong flat in your building!
normalised: Firstly, the format usually starts with the most specific part – your house number or flat number. For example, "Flat Number two hundred and one" or "House Number one hundred and twenty three". In apartment complexes, you will often see something like "A-two hundred and one" where "A" is the block or building name. It is super important to get this right because the postman might just end up delivering it to the wrong flat in your building!

unnormalised: Next up, you have the street name or locality. This could be something like "MG Road" or "Linking Road" in Mumbai. Or, if you're in a smaller place, it might just be the name of the colony, like "Shanti Nagar". Sometimes, people also include a landmark here, something like "Near XYZ School" or "Opposite ABC Hospital". It helps the delivery guys, trust me.
normalised: Next up, you have the street name or locality. This could be something like "M-G Road" or "Linking Road" in Mumbai. Or, if you are in a smaller place, it might just be the name of the colony, like "Shanti Nagar". Sometimes, people also include a landmark here, something like "Near X-Y-Z School" or "Opposite A-B-C Hospital". It helps the delivery guys, trust me.

unnormalised: After the street name, you generally put the city or town. So, for example, "Bangalore" or "Chennai". And then, the really important part – the PIN code! It's a 6-digit number, and it tells the postal service exactly which post office to send your mail to. Without the PIN code, things can get seriously delayed. For instance, "560001" for some parts of Bangalore.
normalised: After the street name, you generally put the city or town. So, for example, "Bangalore" or "Chennai". And then, the really important part – the P-I-N code! It is a six-digit number, and it tells the postal service exactly which post office to send your mail to. Without the P-I-N code, things can get seriously delayed. For instance, "five hundred and sixty thousand and one" for some parts of Bangalore.

unnormalised: The last line is usually the state, like "Karnataka" or "Tamil Nadu". This is less important for domestic mail, but it's essential if you're sending something internationally.
normalised: The last line is usually the state, like "Karnataka" or "Tamil Nadu". This is less important for domestic mail, but it is essential if you are sending something internationally.

normalised: So, putting it all together, a typical residential address in India might look something like this:

unnormalised: Remember, always double-check the address before sending anything! Especially the PIN code. And if you're giving your address to someone over the phone, spell out the street name and repeat the PIN code. Trust me, it’ll save you a lot of headaches. Hopefully, this clarifies things a bit!
